SENT.plain: Fat overload syndrome is a rare complication of intravenous fat emulsion therapy
It is characterized by sudden elevation of the serum triglyceride level, fever, hepatosplenomegaly, coagulopathy, and variable end-organ dysfunction
The illness is generally discrete, and symptoms regress as the lipemia clears
The transient nature of the syndrome has allowed only speculation as to its pathogenesis
The authors report an autopsy study of a child who died during an acute episode of fat overload and document the causative role of fat sludging in the associated end-organ failure

In addition, they offer evidence that the coagulopathy, previously an enigma, results from primary fibrinolysis, possibly caused by release of tissue plasminogen activators from the damaged endothelial cells
